body_html: In your example, the numbers 4 and 3 are the dimensions of the TensorShape, not the data of the tensor (which should indeed be int64). For example, Tesnor t(DT_FLOAT, TensorShape({4,3}) makes sense, but specifying TensorShape({4.5, 3.5}) doesn't (since dimensions must be integers). I'm gonna close this for now, please feel free to continue commenting though.

body: In your example, the numbers 4 and 3 are the dimensions of the TensorShape, not the data of the tensor (which should indeed be int64). For example, Tesnor t(DT_FLOAT, TensorShape({4,3}) makes sense, but specifying TensorShape({4.5, 3.5}) doesn't (since dimensions must be integers).
